qas.question: What is the most common climate across Tennessee?
Most of Tennessee has which type of climate?
Which mountains contain those parts of Tennessee with a temperate climate?
Which body of ocean water affects Tennessee's climate the most?
Which range of months is Tennessee's wettest?
What is Tennessee's average annual precipitation in inches?

context: Most of the state has a <a0_0><a1_0>humid subtropical<a1_0/><a0_0/> climate, with the exception of some of the higher elevations in the <a2_0>Appalachians<a2_0/>, which are classified as having a mountain temperate climate or a humid continental climate due to cooler temperatures. The <a3_0>Gulf of Mexico<a3_0/> is the dominant factor in the climate of Tennessee, with winds from the south being responsible for most of the state's annual precipitation. Generally, the state has hot summers and mild to cool winters with generous precipitation throughout the year, with highest average monthly precipitation generally in the winter and spring months, <a4_0>between December and April<a4_0/>. The driest months, on average, are August to October. On average the state receives <a5_0>50<a5_0/> inches (130 cm) of precipitation annually. Snowfall ranges from 5 inches (13 cm) in West Tennessee to over 16 inches (41 cm) in the higher mountains in East Tennessee.
